translated: Jātaka Stories
Eighty-Nipāta
Cūḷahaṁsavagga🔽Mahāhaṁsa Jātaka
“These geese are flying away,
their wings trembling in fear;
Green-feathered, golden-colored,
if you like, Sumukha, fly away.
Abandoning me, a relative,
who has fallen into a trap,
they are going without concern;
why do you alone abandon me?
Fly, fly, best of fliers,
there is no friendship with the bound;
Do not abandon me, who is without fear,

analyzed: kāmam su mukha pakkama  na aham dukkha paretaḥ api
translated: if you like, Sumukha, fly away.”🔽“I will not abandon you, Dhataraṭṭha,
even if it leads to suffering for me;
My life or death,

analyzed: tayā saddhim bhavissati  na aham dukkha paretaḥ api
translated: will be with you.🔽I will not abandon you, Dhataraṭṭha,
even if it leads to suffering for me;
You are not fit to employ me
in a task connected with the unrighteous.
Since childhood you have been my friend,
and I am established in your mind;
I am known as your general,
the supreme of geese.
How can I go from here
into the midst of my relatives?
Abandoning me, who is flying away, best of fliers,
what will you say when you go there?
Here I will give up my life,
I cannot do what is unmanly.”
“This is the way, Sumukha,
that you stand on the noble path;
You who cannot give up me,
your master and friend.
For when I look at you,
fear does not arise in me;
You will attain my life,
when it is in this state.”
Thus as they were consulting,
the nobles with noble conduct,
the fowler, taking his stick,
quickly and noisily approached.
Seeing him approaching,
Sumukha spoke thus:
He stood in front of the king,
the goose, out of confidence, spoke thus.
“Do not be afraid, best of fliers,
such as you are not afraid;
I will apply the yoke,
the yoke connected with the Dhamma;
By that means of escape,
you will quickly be freed from the snare.”
Having heard his words,
Sumukha’s well spoken words,
the fowler, with his hair standing on end,
made his hands into a respectful salutation.

translated: “I have neither heard nor seen,

analyzed: ariyam bruvānaḥ vakkaṅgaḥ  cajantaḥ mānusim gira

original: Kiṁ nu tāyaṁ dijo hoti,🔽mutto baddhaṁ upāsasi;
analyzed: kim nu tāyam dijaḥ  muttaḥ baddham upāsasi
translated: Why is he a bird?🔽He is free, but he serves the bound.
The birds fly away,
Why do you alone stay behind?”
“He is my friend, the bird,
I made him the general of the army.
I have given him up,
I can serve the lord of the birds.
He is my lord, the great one,
Do not go alone to destruction.
So, good hunter,
Serve your lord and enjoy yourself.”
“You are acting nobly, Vakkaṅga,
In serving the alms-food.
I give up that lord of yours,
You may both go as you please.”
“If I have been brought down🔽By my own means, the bird,
We accept that, good hunter,
This gift of fearlessness.

analyzed: no ce atta ppayogena  ohitaḥ hasapakkhina
translated: If I have not been brought down🔽By my own means, the bird,
We are not in control,
You may kill us, hunter.”
“To whom you are a servant, the king,
Take him and go to him.
The king is self-controlled there,
will do as he wishes.”
Thus spoken to, the fowler,
with his golden-coloured, green-feathered (birds),
after clasping them with both hands,
put them into the cage.
Those two birds, who were in the cage,
both of them golden-coloured,
Sumukha and Dhataraṭṭha,
the fowler took and left.
While being carried off Dhataraṭṭha,🔽said this to Sumukha:
“I am afraid, Sumukha,
of the one with the thighs like an elephant’s foot;
thinking of our destruction,
he will now kill himself.
The wild geese, Sumukha,
golden, with golden neck-strings;
the female Konca on the ocean shore,
is surely pleased with the fool.”
“So great is the world,
incalculable, a great multitude;
a human being is of one mind,
this is not like the wise.
Like the wind smells a scent,
both are of the worst kind;
like a fool a raw and ripe (fruit),
the fool is greedy for food.
One who is not skilled in matters,
the fool spoke to me:
You do not know what should and should not be done,
the time has come for you.”
The one who thinks these women are the best,
is like a fool who thinks he’s drunk
when he’s just got a mouthful of beer.

original: Māyā cesā marīcī ca,🔽soko rogo cupaddavo;
analyzed: māyā ca isā marīcī ca  sokaḥ rogaḥ cupaddavaḥ
translated: These are illusion, mirage,🔽sorrow, disease, and disaster.
They are harsh and binding,
the noose of Death, the lair of the cave.
The man who trusts in them
is the worst of men.”
“What is approved by the wise,
who is there to blame it?
The great elements are called
the women who have appeared in the world.
Play is placed in them,
delight is established in them.
Seeds grow in them,
that is, beings are born.
What man would be disgusted with them,
and strike them with his hands?

Seeing the two of them, both of whom were marked with signs of merit,
the self-controlled king
addressed his ministers:
“Give the hunter clothes,
food, drink, and meals,
He can have as much gold
as he desires.”
Seeing the hunter’s delight,
the King of Kāsi said this:
“If this is so, my good Khemaka,
and this lake is full of geese,
How did you come here with a noose in your hand,
having gone through the middle of the flock?
How did you catch one that is surrounded by a multitude of relatives,
that is not solitary?”
“Today is the seventh night
since I have been seeking alms.
Searching for his tracks,
I was heedful and diligent.
Then I saw his track
as he was going about seeking alms.
There I threw my noose,
and thus I caught the bird.”

“We are not afraid, O Sumukha,

“I am not afraid, O lord of Kāsi,
I have been brought to life;
I will speak words that are meaningful,
having attained the right time.
He who kills one deer with another,
or a bird with another bird;
Or a heard with a heard,
what is more undignified than that?
One who speaks like a crying child,
who is drenched in undignified things,
he fails in both worlds,
in this world and the next.
Do not get drunk when you have attained fame,
do not get sick when you have attained doubt;
Strive in your duties,
and restrain the openings (to temptation).
Those who are old and have passed away,
who have attained the time of death;
Having practiced the Dhamma here,
thus they have gone to the Heavenly World.
Having heard this, O Lord of Kasi,
guard your mind with the Dhamma;
And release Dhataraṭṭha,
the most excellent of swans.
Bring water and a mirror,

I will release from the cage

Who is happy when the king is happy,

Such a one is worthy
